Message.Title: intels equity stake in ASML made a sheetload compared
Message.Msg: to the hedge fund monkeys from Nomura Nomura Securities maintains a 'Neutral' on ASML Inc. (NASDAQ: ASML) price target of EUR42.00. Analyst, Carmen Boyero, said, "ASML reported Q2 results that were in-line with previous guidance and consensus expectations. Systems sales were 5% below expectations, however, driven by lower ASP. Q2 sales were primarily driven by foundry and logic continuing the trend in previous quarters. Net bookings increased qoq to 949m and 43 systems, although backlog continued the declining trend to EUR 1,503m and 55 systems (from EUR 1,598m and 56 systems)...Guidance for the full year 2012 is seen at between EUR 4.6b and EUR 4.8b, or 3% below market expectations of EUR 4,863m." Note: Nomura downgraded ASML from Buy to Neutral on July 13th. To see the report, click here For an analyst ratings summary and ratings history on ASML Inc. click here. For more ratings news on ASML Inc. click here. Shares of ASML Inc. closed at $51.50 yesterday, with a 52 week range of $30.65-$53.30.

Topic.Title: Intel: Major Catalyst Coming On July 22

Message.Msg: Brian Krzanich and Stacy Smith sounds EXTREMELY confident Data Center group will grow by double digits this year: Brian M. Krzanich - CEO Sure. This is Brian. I'll answer that one. Yeah, so we're still confident in the second half growth of our data center business overall. As we mentioned, we're seeing strong growth in the cloud, the high performance computing, our networking and our storage. We think those continue through the second half of this year. What was down as Stacy mentioned was – the enterprise data centers were down a bit in the first half. We think as the macroeconomics continue to improve through this year that picks up a bit. When you put that all together, we believe that – absolutely our view is that we can continue through this year with that low double digit growth. Stacy J. Smith - EVP and CFO Yeah. And from a [wonky] finance standpoint, realize there's also kind of prior period comparisons been going on in the first half of last year. We were in the steep part of the ramp for Romley. In the second half of this year, we'll be launching other versions of Ivy versions of the data center. So the short answer to your question is yes, I would expect some pretty steep quarter-on-quarter and year-on-year comps in the back half of this year. That is what we're planning for.

Topic.Title: Intel: Major Catalyst Coming On July 22

Message.Msg: I was looking at the "Trended Financial Statements" at Intel's investor relation website and did some simple calculations in terms of revenues. If Data Center group grows by 11%-12%, then the PC Client group would only need to be flat (year-over-year) for second half to meet Intel's guidance of flat revenues. This is extremely unlikely given that "Haswell along with Bay Trail will power more than 50 different two-in-one devices in the pipeline, including the very first fanless Core design." Not to mention addition revenues from Bay Trail 7"-10" Android tablets, a market Intel did not participate in last year. I think BK and SS were being extremely cautious with their lowered guidance.

Topic.Title: Windows 8 is what is killing PC's

Message.Msg: Completely agree. If Windows 7 supported touch Ultra-books would have taken off and ramped beyond anyone's expectations. Having to wait for Windows 8 stalled the market, and when it arrived turned people off because it is so terrible. (lest we forget,... At Microsoft Quality is Job 1.1) Ballmer is the last man standing from the folks who started Microsoft, and he was a Gates, and Allen hanger on with nothing of genuine value to offer. And he has done nothing if not for having nurtured a culture of over the top corporate arrogance that makes you want to root with all your heart for their utter demise. The sooner the computing industry rids itself of the last vestiges of Microsoft's bloatware the better off all will all be.

Message.Title: Two very large, dishonest derivative players will bring down the world financial markets.
Message.Msg: Opened my eyes just in time to see a rather large nurse holding a syringe. As two orderlies wrestled me to the ground, felt a needle jab deep inside my arm. Next, my arms were stuffed into a jacket that looked backwards to me. Soon I felt immobilized as the straps from the jacket were tightened. Before I knew it, I was lying on a table in a room that had a funny burning smell. A strange looking machine was wheeled close to me. What looked like electrodes were attached to both sides of my head. A wooden stick was placed inside my mouth and was told to bite down. As I glanced up, one of the attendants dressed in white pulled down a large lever ........ What seemed like only seconds, I went whirling back in time and was back at the pool party in Long Island. Kate Upton led me into a bedroom and began to unzip my pants...........I smiled broadly as she began to kneel... I ......,

Message.Title: What We Know Now: The Big Deal Issue
Message.Msg: Here's what we know now (from the headline): Intel on Track with Volume 14nm (FinFET) Production This Year "Intel to Produce Broadwell Chips Later in 2013" And this provides the upside and Intel's wildcard and ace-in-the-hole for this year. Intel is going to sign some big deals. Some very big deals. They aren't building all that 14nm FinFET capacity for nothing. And no company is going to let the competition leap two years ahead on process technology if they can help it. This advanced technology is going to be very much in demand. Why haven't we heard about them yet? Because that's how it's done. In order to avoid souring relations with existing vendors, announcements are closely guarded. We already know about one such deal that was confirmed by Intel with a major mobility player. We also know that Intel is working on smartwatches with somebody. There will be these and others. And when it happens, it is going to blow the socks off of the shorts. What we also know now is that it is going to become much clearer this year that Intel is taking market share from ARM. The shipment of Intel's 14nm FinFET is going to dramatically emphasis this trend. Look for this recognition to knock the stuffing out of ARM's P/E ratio and to enhance Intel's P/E ratio. I believe that this year , P/E ratios will drive the Intel stock price as much or more than earnings. 2013: Year of the Intel Tablet and Year of the Lumpy Intel Big Deal Announcements and Stock Price Surge 2014: Year of the Intel Smartphone and More Lumpy Intel Big Deal Announcements and Stock Price Surges

Message.Title: Haswell chips can give a laptop workstation power
Message.Msg: I'm not really sure why Intel isn't pushing the new Haswell-based chips a little harder, as they seem to have been released with a whisper. When the first i-generation of chips was released -- the i3s, i5s and i7s -- there was a huge campaign to show how revolutionary they were compared to previous models. But now we are seeing the fourth generation Haswell-based chips, and almost nothing is being said about them. But then again, perhaps the performance speaks for itself. Yes, they are amazing. For such low-power consumption, there’s more raw power than most people know what to do with. And even when they’re not running at maximum speed, they’ll still help extend battery life. Laptops with Haswell chips could help enable mobile computing and teleworking for agency employees who need a powerful system. The latest product to take advantage of the Haswell Intel Core i7 processor is the Scorpius 2.0 notebook from Eurocom. Even without the Haswell processor, the Scorpius is an impressive unit. It's got dual Nvidia GeForce GTX 780M graphics cards and 8G of DDR5 video memory driving its 17.1-inch screen. There are a lot of options for connecting devices into it too, including HDMI 1.4, Thunderbolt, four USB 3.0 ports and an eSATA/USB 2.0 combo port. But what really blew us away was the performance. It scored 4,576 on the Passmark Performance Benchmarks without any overclocking at all. For a notebook, that is about as impressive as it gets today. Consider the fact that the powerful Tiki workstation got up to 5,618 last year using a previous generation processor, or the fact that the most modern workstation we've ever benchmarked, the Origin Systems Chronos Pro got 6,131 just last month. But they didn't have access to this new chipset, which apparently gives mere notebooks access to workstation-level performance. But it's important to note that despite the lack of fanfare, another great leap forward has occurred. From gcn

Message.Title: Just A Thought
Message.Msg: The DJIA has put together a four week win streak that entered the weekend overbought. Investors seem comfortable with the Feds withdraw of easy money stimulus and signs that Europe and some of the emerging markets are gaining traction are helping to push stocks higher. New money is coming into the market at a record pace and the economic outlook looks stronger than anticipated. Looks like nothing can go wrong! That may be the fly in the ointment. Although the second half outlook remains strong, bullish sentiment is getting overdone. Going into another strong week of earnings any pullback in the market will be bought quickly and downside seems limited but, any time the crowd gets overzealous a round of profit taking might be in the cards. The summer rally may be due for a short term pause. Have a nice weekend.

Topic.Title: Intel: Major Catalyst Coming On July 22

Message.Msg: (Tomorrow) *** I cannot stress this enough, but there is a major upside catalyst coming for Intel (INTC) on July 22. When I checked Intel's investor relations site for any upcoming events, I saw the following: Reimagine the Datacenter 07/22/13 -8:00 AM PT Speaker: Diane Bryant, SVP, General Manager, Datacenter and Connected Systems Group While this seems innocent enough, and for most investors it may not appear to be of consequence, I believe that on this webcast Intel will be announcing its next generation micro-server and networking infrastructure parts based on the Silvermont core known as Avoton and Rangeley, respectively. I believe that many investors are completely unaware of the magnitude of these launches, particularly as the sell side has remained mum in light of their promotion of ARM Holdings' (ARMH) data-center aspirations. These launches will dramatically change the investing landscape, and I will detail why in this article. From Ashraf Eassa

Message.Title: iPhone 5S/6 To Use Intel....
Message.Msg: The Apple’s AX processors will soon become obsolete. According to the new reports, an alliance between Apple & Intel is taking place, and it is for sure bad news for Samsung. According to some sources, Intel & Apple are amidst of a deal that involves production of a complete new range of ARM processors specially meant for mobile devices. Apple’s processors such as A5 & A6 are pretty good and are doing fine with iPad 4 & iPhone 5, but they are manufactured by the Samsung…its chief rival. And each year Apple is shelling out eight figure sum to Samsung to keep iPads & iPhones running in the market. We will very soon be hearing about an iPhone 5S or an iPhone 6 release with Intel mobile processor this very same year.

Topic.Title: iPhone 5S/6 To Use Intel....

Message.Msg: from wsj Mr. Krzanich gave new details of plans to use the Atom technology and other new building-block components to boost the company's budding "foundry" business, which makes chips for other companies. He disclosed that Intel has been working to offer customers blocks of specialized circuitry, along with its processors, so they can mix and match combinations to create customizable chips for their products. -------------------------------- from Reuters "If there was a great customer that we had a great relationship with laptops and other mobile devices, and they said look, we'd really love you to build our ARM-based product, we'd consider it. It depends on how strategic they are," Krzanich said.
